Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I was able to truly become a better writer following this course. The constant interaction between my other peers and the professor helped to improve my writing drastically throughout the semester.
How to be a better writer, how to evaluate and better my own and other peoples work

My writing definitely improved throughout the course, especially since I'm just a STEM major who is far from interested in prose writing. I also learned a lot about how claims can be written and presented, which I think will be invaluable.
I gained the ability to think about modern philosophical texts and develop my own ideas related to the self and the self in artificial intelligence. I also able to improve my writing skills.
I learned many writing skills that will really help me going forward. I really enjoyed learning from Professor Eklund!

I learned a lot throughout this course. First of all, I learned plenty of information about the self and what construct us as people. Most importantly, i learned how to properly put my thoughts onto paper and create and essay that is, I guess, Yale level. Became a much better writer.
This course allowed me to evaluate what Im doing wrong in my writing and gave me many ways to fix the issues I had.

My writing skills greatly improved, as well as my ability to properly structure an argument and an essay. I know understand how to identify a problem, make my claim, and provide evidence for the claim throughout the essay in an insightful and interesting way.

The readings are super interesting, easy to engage with, and exposed me to a variety of different writing styles. I would say that I wish there was more time spent on workshopping papers, especially the research paper, however this was addressed towards the end of the course.
Engaging, small group setting was good for discussions

This was one of my favorite classes of the semester, so I don't have many qualms. The readings were fun and the essay prompts weren't that stressful. Overall, it was a very engaging course that offers a great transition from high-school level to college-level writing. Also, the teacher is just awesome.

The course is discussion based and really helps communication skills and idea building.  The different types of papers allowed me to be exposed to different types of writing.  The range of the topics covered in the course ensure that the same topic is not exhausted, keeping the class interesting. On the downside, some of the readings could be changed to better fit the course.

The discussions, peer workshops and ample, detailed feedback received on each of the four essays were all very helpful and definite strengths of the course. At times, however, we would stray off the syllabus dates and it was a bit difficult to figure out when different readings were actually due.

Strength: 
Teaches you how to write 
Teacher was engaged and passionate
Readings were interesting 
Flexible with deadlines
Cons:
Essays would pile up and itd be difficult to keep up with all of them.

Strengths: small class, interesting material, good discussion & discussion was encouraged, received good feedback on my writing from the professor, professor really wanted us to do well. Weaknesses: Peer feedback was hit or miss depending on who I was paired with, some assignments lacked clarity. Improving: Maybe showing the class what to look out for when giving feedback and how to give constructive feedback, clarifying the guidelines for the assignments and being more specific.
I would highly recommend this course to another student  it truly develops you as a writer and engages the student with stimulating questions about the self.
Yes, I think its important to improve your reading and writing skills no matter what you want to do in the future

Definitely. It's also a great way to get writing credit for STEM majors and the information one learns from this class is actually quite interesting. Writing a research assignment also strengthened my confidence in doing such papers.

I would recommend this course as you get a good introduction to some modern philosophical text, but also will have the opportunity to improve you writing ability and receive clear, detailed feedback on your writing.
Yes I would because it really helps your writing move from high school level to college level.
Yes, teacher does a well job engaging and is flexible with deadlines if you need it.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. The prospect of writing a college-level essay was absolutely daunting to me coming in as a first-year, and this course, and Professor Eklund, completely demystified the process for me! I feel like my writing has improved tremendously and I'm now able to write long, cohesive, interesting papers that properly convey what I'm trying to say. This is great for people that want to focus on improving their academic writing.
